plausible_answers.text: the CD to dominate the at-home music market unchallenged.

qas.question: How were customers disadvantaged by the Philips and Sony merger?

context: The Compact Disc is an evolution of <a3_0>LaserDisc<a3_0/> technology, where a focused laser beam is used that enables the high information density required for high-quality digital audio signals. Prototypes were developed by <a0_0><b7_0>Philips<b7_0/> and Sony<a0_0/> independently in the <b9_0>late 1970s<b9_0/>. In 1979, Sony and Philips set up a joint task force of engineers to design a new digital audio disc. After <a1_0>a year<a1_0/> of experimentation and discussion, the Red Book CD-DA standard was published in 1980. After their commercial release in <a6_0>1982<a6_0/>, compact discs and their players were extremely popular. Despite costing up to $1,000, over <a2_0><b8_0>400,000<b8_0/><a2_0/> CD players were sold in the United States <b10_0>between 1983 and 1984<b10_0/>. The success of the compact disc has been credited to the <a5_0>cooperation between Philips and Sony<a5_0/>, who came together to agree upon and develop compatible hardware. The <a4_0>unified design<a4_0/> of the compact disc allowed consumers to purchase any disc or player from any company, and allowed <b11_0>the CD to dominate the at-home music market unchallenged.
